key_insight: GriDiT factorizes long image-sequence generation into a grid of localized diffusion processes with lightweight cross-grid conditioning, drastically reducing compute and memory while preserving global temporal/spatial coherence.
problem_solved: Current methods treat long image sequences as huge stacked tensors, leading to poor scalability, high memory use, and slow sampling; GriDiT addresses efficient, scalable generative modeling for very long image sequences.
method: Partition the spatio-temporal volume into a grid of local cells and run factorized diffusion processes per cell instead of operating on a single giant tensor.
Exchange compact cross-cell conditioning signals (e.g., sparse attention or conditioning channels) to maintain global consistency across the grid.
Use hierarchical/progressive sampling across grid levels or time windows to enable linear scaling in compute and faster inference for long sequences.
impact: Makes diffusion-based generation practical for much longer image sequences with lower memory and compute, enabling applications such as long-form video synthesis, animation, and large-scale data augmentation.

paper_title: GriDiT: Factorized Grid-Based Diffusion for Efficient Long Image Sequence Generation
paper_authors: Snehal Singh Tomar, Alexandros Graikos, Arjun Krishna, Dimitris Samaras, Klaus Mueller
